ja:head.ce:title: Two neuro-fuzzy control schemes for a traffic-regulating buffer in wireless technology

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Intelligent Systems Research Centre, Faculty of Computing, London Metropolitan University, Tower Building, 166-220 Holloway Road, London N7 8DB, UK

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Bluetooth wireless operates in 2.4-GHz Industrial Scientific and Medicine (ISM) frequency, which may interfere with other devices functioning within the same frequency band, such as WiFi. Furthermore, Moving Picture Expert Group (MPEG) variable bit rate (VBR) video demands larger and more stable bandwidth and may cause data loss and time delay as a result of the high variation in bit rate in Bluetooth channels with limited bandwidth. To address these issues, two new neuro-fuzzy schemes are developed to control the input and output of a buffer referred to here as the traffic-regulating buffer. Regarding the input of this buffer, a rule-based fuzzy scheme is introduced and supervised by a neural network technique as a master controller to monitor the arrival rate to the buffer. The output of the traffic-regulating buffer is observed by another rule-based fuzzy scheme and is supervised by a second neural network to monitor the departure rate. Computer simulation results demonstrate that the two proposed neuro-fuzzy models reduce standard deviation and excessive data loss, and they also show an improved picture quality as compared with conventional MPEG VBR video over a Bluetooth channel.

ce:section.ce:para: Soft computing techniques, such as neural networks, fuzzy logic and neuro-fuzzy, are suitable for non-linear, poorly defined, unpredictable and imprecise systems. Due to uncertainty of data transmission and distribution over wired and wireless technology, artificial neural networks [25], fuzzy logic [6,31,32] and neuro-fuzzy systems [24] have been applied to communication networks to improve performance. For example, in the past few years, research has been carried out to apply neural networks to video in wired and wireless networks, such as video conferencing, MPEG-4 VBR traffic prediction and video over wireless technology, with various degree of success [29,17,28]. Fuzzy logic also has been applied to wireless medium access control for assignment of resources for video/audio, the priority scheduler in Mobile Ad hoc NETworks and video variable bit rate streaming over Digital Video Broadcasting for Handheld (DVB-H) terminals [18,7,22].

Furthermore, neuro-fuzzy systems have been extensively utilized in communication to optimize performance. Some of applications of neuro-fuzzy systems to data transmission in networks are described below. Yuang and Tien [30] proposed a new intelligent multiple access control system (IMACS) with dynamic bandwidth allocation of wireless asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) networks. A traffic estimator/predictor (TEP) performs periodic estimation and on-line prediction of available bit rate (ABR) based on wavelet analysis and a neuro-fuzzy technique. An intelligent bandwidth allocator monitors dynamic bandwidth allocation for ABR and signaling control traffic by determining the optimal splitting depth using TEP. The experimental results show that using a back propagation neural network and a neuro-fuzzy in IMACS offer various QoS guarantees and maximize network throughput regardless of traffic variation. Garcia et al. [5] developed fuzzy and neuro-fuzzy approaches to object tracking based on sequences of video images for surveillance of airports. The experimental results from the automatic surveillance of ground operation show that the system is capable of solving complex scenarios and improving tracking accuracy, with robustness, flexibility in the design’s adaptation to different situations, efficiency of real-time operation and avoidance of combinatorial enumeration. Chimmanee et al. [4] applied a hybrid neuro-fuzzy technique to a load-balancing tool to take into account the current status of applications and network resources. The results show the optimization of QoS requirement for delay-sensitive applications and appropriate utilization of network resources. Abdennour [1] presented an adaptive neuro-fuzzy as a generic framework for predicting network traffics such as MPEG broadcasting video sequences. Four predictors are developed. Three are designed to perform a single-step-ahead prediction for Intra, Predicted and Bi-directional frames. The fourth is used to predict the multiple steps of the smoothed time series of the entire movie sequence. The overall conclusion is that adaptive neuro-fuzzy is capable of providing accurate predictions and has the added advantage of being simple to design and implement as compared to conventional designs. Kodogiannis et al. [15] proposed an integrated neuro-fuzzy learning scheme for detecting abnormal patterns in wireless capsule endoscopy (WCE) images. In summary, the high detection accuracy of neuro-fuzzy systems suggests that such an intelligent technique could be used as a supplementary diagnostic tool in WCE. Alotaibi et al. [2] proposed an adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) model for a robust prediction of wireless signal in the City of Riyadh. The results show that the neuro-fuzzy prediction model outperforms other conventional prediction models such as deterministic, empirical, as well as statistical models. The neuro-fuzzy field strength prediction is more flexible in adapting to different environments, able to process a high quantity of data, and also has high-speed processing power. Chen et al. [3] recently applied an ANFIS to admission control over wideband code division with multiple access in a Wireless Local Area Network for multimedia traffic. The ANFIS is a fuzzy Q-learning admission controller. Simulation results show that the ANFIS can always maintain the system’s QoS requirement up to a traffic intensity of 1.1, as it can appropriately admit or reject the user’s admission requests. The ANFIS further reduces the handoff rate by 15–20%.

Razavi et al. [21] presented a fuzzy logic control for the Bluetooth’s default automatic repeat request for video transmission. The fuzzy logic approach considers both the delay constraints of the video stream while simultaneously avoiding buffer overflow. For adverse channel conditions and buffer size, the tests show an improvement of at least 4 dB in video quality as compared to non-fuzzy schemes. Kazemian and Chantaraskul [13] developed a rule-based fuzzy controller and a neuro-fuzzy controller to monitor the arrival rate and the departure rate of a traffic-regulating buffer to smooth video transmission over Bluetooth. The computer simulation results demonstrate that the two controllers reduce the data loss and standard deviation of video while increasing the overall data distribution, thereby resulting in improved picture quality. Moreover, the fuzzy approach to quantization speeds up the transmission rate. This paper takes the research further by introducing two neuro-fuzzy controllers and expanding on these results. The overall objective of this research is to reduce data loss and improve the quality of the picture. MPEG video at the input and output of the traffic-regulating buffer is monitored and manipulated by two new neuro-fuzzy controllers to guarantee smooth transmission of data over wireless technology, thus accommodating for the volatility in video signal and channel condition. Section 2 explains the structure of the MPEG digital video and the 2.4-GHz Bluetooth channel utilized in this paper. Section 3 describes the two proposed neuro-fuzzy controllers developed for the arrival rate and departure rate of the traffic regulator. Section 4 outlines the computer simulation results, and Section 5 presents overall conclusions from the research.

Existing packet-switching techniques are not entirely adequate for digital video transmission over wireless technologies with limited bandwidth, as packets can be delayed and even lost. The delays involved in re-transmitting packets means that the quality of the reproduction of the information upon reception deteriorates to the point of unintelligibility. Engineers and policy makers have attempted to provide solutions to these problems in at least three ways, that is, by building higher bandwidth wireless networks, developing more efficient transmission and packet-switching techniques, and applying more sophisticated data compression techniques. This paper proposes a new method so that data-hungry digital video such as MPEG can be transmitted over bandwidth-limited standards such as Bluetooth. This paper utilizes a novel soft computing technique to manipulate and reduce the burstiness of MPEG video data during the transmission period in order to reduce data loss. In general, data loss in digital video happens during the transmission process, which occurs in effect as packet loss. Packet loss is mainly caused by congestion in the network. The major setback of packet loss is that it may lead to degradation in video quality, as MPEG compression uses temporal dependencies and motion compensation. Therefore, handling and recovering from packet loss has been widely researched in video transmission. In this paper, we propose a system that recognizes the channel situation and provides appropriate transmission speed in order to adjust to bandwidth availability, hence reducing packet loss and delay during the transmission process.

MPEG video compression exploits the similarities or redundancies between consecutive frames or images that exists in video signal. This technique has a major advantage in reducing the size of video stream. MPEG-encoding provides constant video quality by statically setting the quantization scale [23,14] for Intra (I), Predicted (P), and Bi-directional (B) frames for the variable bit rates. The intra-coded picture is encoded independently, without passing through the temporal model, which contains the most original information, hence, the most data bits. The predictive-coded picture is encoded by using the previous I- or P-picture as a reference frame to obtain predictions, which are transmitted to the receiver along with the error compensation obtained from the compensation process. The bi-directionally predictive-coded picture is similar to the P-picture. However, it obtains predictions from the previous I- or P-pictures or the following I- or P- pictures. The B-picture can use both the previous and the next I- or P- pictures in this process. Under the highest degree of compression, the B- picture contains the fewest data bits, and furthermore, it highly depends on the reference frame(s). In MPEG, the group of pictures (GOP) is a group of frames between successive I-frames; the others are P-frames and B-frames. In the widest application of the Phase Alternate Line, the GOP is usually 12 frames in 25 frames per second, as outlined in Fig. 1 .

In this paper, only the B-picture is dropped, as the loss of B-picture does not affect other frames in the GOP. The MPEG decoder therefore must be modified in order to cope with the loss of B-picture. This is accomplished by replacing the missing information with the default values in order to complete the stream for each component. The components are subsequently ready to be decoded. In general, there are two types of MPEG video coding, namely, constant bit rate (CBR) coding and variable bit rate (VBR) coding [20]. For video communication applications, especially via dynamic channels, CBR coding is employed. For example, CBR is utilized for digital TV and video conferencing over ISDN. In contrast, VBR provides the option of fixing and controlling the picture quality by varying the bit rate. This type of coding provides constant video quality by statically setting the quantization scale for I-, P- and B-frames, whereas the bit rate is allowed to vary. VBR coding offers a low bit rate for scenes such as still frames, and a larger bit rate for those moving images that require more data to maintain constant image quality. This paper employs VBR to maintain a constant video quality.

In this paper, a Bluetooth channel is utilized to represent 2.4-GHz wireless frequency. Bluetooth is structured as such to offer two types of links, namely, the Synchronous Connection-Oriented (SCO) link and Asynchronous Connection-Less (ACL) link [8,10]. The SCO link is normally used to carry real-time traffic such as audio and video. The SCO link employs a slot reservation mechanism, which permits the periodic transmission of SCO data and guarantees bandwidth and delay. However it does not provide reliability because the SCO payload is not protected by a Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC), and there are no re-transmissions. In contrast, the ACL link is suitable for data applications. The ACL link can offer both symmetric and asymmetric bandwidth. ACL may support 1000 kb/s downlink using DH5 packets, which is suitable for MPEG video transmission. The ACL payload is protected by error-checking schemes. When error checking fails, a re-transmission is performed, unless the pre-set flush timeout timer expires. In this paper, the ACL link of the Bluetooth channel is utilized for computer simulations, as it offers error-checking schemes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Use of neuro-fuzzy techniques for arrival rate and departure rate
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 2 presents the overall structure of two neuro-fuzzy control schemes for a traffic-regulating buffer in 2.4-GHz wireless technology. The Host Controller Interface (HCI) of the Bluetooth protocol stack is the point of interface between software and hardware, where the digital signal propagates at a frequency of 2.4-GHz. Fig. 2 comprises of an MPEG Encoder, a generic cell rate algorithm hereafter referred to as a token bucket and a traffic-regulating buffer. The MPEG encoder encodes the incoming Audio Video Interleave (AVI). The conventional token bucket is based on a popular policing mechanism, which is associated with wireless and wired networks. A token bucket is a rate-policing buffer by which data streams can be judged to comply with the wireless traffic contract [12]. The token bucket and the associated policing mechanisms are mostly inadequate to sufficiently regulate the transmission of MPEG VBR video data over a 2.4-GHz wireless standard. The traditional token bucket buffers and leak rates with queuing management techniques are all fixed. The queuing management techniques use fixed thresholds and a limited number of arrival frames to ascertain when to allow or flush the entry of frames. Therefore, the conventional token buckets are not adequately controlled to meet the quality of picture required for a 2.4-GHz frequency band [16]. This work introduces another buffer called the traffic-regulating buffer before the departure rate to smooth the traffic entering the network, conform to traffic conditions, and prevent excessive back-to-back data streams from being generated during the peak transmissions of MPEG video. In policing the MPEG VBR traffic, the video stream is measured against the contracted peak rate of the Bluetooth channel, which is taken as 1000 kbps. In this paper, two original neuro-fuzzy methods entitled the arrival rate NF scheme and the departure rate NF scheme are developed to control input and output of the traffic-regulating buffer in order to reduce data loss and improve picture quality, as described in detail below.

.The two NF schemes are implemented using the adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) function, which simulates neuro-fuzzy training of the Sugeno-type fuzzy inference system. Computer simulations have been conducted for the two NF schemes and compared with the conventional VBR system. Conventional VBR system is comprised of a MPEG encoder and a generic cell rate algorithm (token bucket). Two video clips entitled ‘Superman Returns’ and ‘The Santa Clause 3’ are used to implement the proposed system in the simulations [9]. The two video clips are utilized to present two scenarios. The two NF schemes can either reduce the data loss significantly or eliminate it completely depending on the application and the requirements at the receiving end of the device. The computer simulation results are shown in Section 4.1. ‘Superman Returns’ and 4.2. ‘The Santa Clause 3’, which demonstrate the two scenarios in detail. For computer simulation, a 2.4-GHz ISM frequency channel, IEEE 802.15.1 – Bluetooth, is used for video streaming [11].

Figs. 5 and 6
for ‘Superman Returns’ provide a comparison of the compressed video stream for the two NF schemes and the conventional VBR scheme. Fig. 5 demonstrates a lower concentration of GOP size in one area for the two NF schemes, more distribution and less burstiness, which reduces the data loss and time delay. The probability density and histogram in Fig. 6 shows that the density of ‘Superman Returns’ is slightly greater and GOP size is more with a larger number of bits, that is, more data availability for transmission and consequently, better image quality using the two NF schemes. Table 2 is a supplement to Figs. 5 and 6; it provides summarized hard values for both plots, showing that the standard deviation of the two NF systems is lower than the standard deviation obtained for the conventional VBR system because smaller standard deviation offers less burstiness. In Table 2, the GOP size is averaged for both methods, and there are more GOP sizes for the two NF schemes than the VBR scheme, which implies more data for transmission and hence better picture quality.

Fig. 7 provides the results for the conventional VBR system for the arrival rate R a and the actual bandwidth or actual transmission rate r actual . Fig. 8 depicts the available space in the conventional token bucket. The token bucket buffer works such that the more token is taken, the less storage is available to keep the video data, hence resulting in data loss. Fig. 9 shows the two proposed NF schemes with R d from the traffic-regulating buffer. As shown, the two NF schemes manipulate the MPEG encoder and regulate the bit rate in order to decrease the burstiness much better than the conventional VBR system, which results in reduction in data loss and delays and thus better image quality.

Fig. 10 shows separate plots for each buffer, the conventional token bucket and the traffic regulator from the proposed design. A token bucket buffer availability below 0 and a traffic regulator queue length above 1 indicate that the system is experiencing a drop in data. The traffic-regulating buffer works such that the more stored video data there is, the lesser buffer will be available, resulting in values shifting from 0 to 1. The data loss in Fig. 10 is at the traffic-regulating buffer, through which the degree of loss can be easily manipulated by constantly monitoring the capacities of the two buffers and the network in real-time, thus facilitating a scenario in which the video data is predominantly lost at the traffic-regulating buffer. There is no loss at the token bucket buffer. Fig. 11 is provided for comparison purposes. Fig. 11 is the compatible plot for the dropped data under the two NF schemes, and it is calculated by adding values from both buffers and re-plotting as if the system has only one buffer, that is, the token bucket with no NF schemes. Fig. 11 can therefore be compared with the dropped data plot of the token bucket from the VBR system in Fig. 8. The overall data drop is much greater in the VBR system in Fig. 8 than in the two NF schemes in Fig. 11. Furthermore, Table 3 provides figures for the conventional VBR system and the two NF schemes. There is no traffic-regulating buffer for the conventional VBR system and the overall dropped data through the token bucket is 2.6605%. With the two NF schemes, there is no data loss at the token bucket; rather, the loss is at the traffic-regulating buffer, and the overall data loss is 0.4991%. It can therefore be concluded that the percentage of data loss using the conventional VBR system is substantially greater that under the two proposed NF schemes. As stated in Section 2, the B-picture is allowed be dropped in this work. The motion vector is a very important aspect of reconstructing the image for the B-picture. With a full set or a portion of the motion vector, the image can be reconstructed from the reference frame(s) [23]. Distortion therefore results from the missing parts of the AC coefficient and DC coefficient. The MPEG decoder is designed to be able to find the missing information for the DC and AC coefficients by substituting the default values to complete the stream for each component. The components are subsequently ready to be decoded. In the next clip, ‘The Santa Clause 3’ demonstrates that using the two NF schemes can eliminate data loss altogether, resulting in a standard deviation that is decreased significantly in order to reduce burstiness. In addition, the average GOP size is reduced slightly to avoid data loss.

Figs. 12 and 13
provide a comparison of video stream for the two NF schemes and the conventional VBR scheme for ‘The Santa Clause 3’ clip. Fig. 12 demonstrates a lower concentration of GOP size in one area for the two NF schemes, a broader distribution and a significant reduction in burstiness, resulting in no data loss and reduced time delay. The probability density and histogram in Fig. 13 shows that the density is greater and the GOP size (bit) is less as compared to the conventional VBR scheme; that is, there is slightly less data for transmission and consequently no data loss under the two proposed NF schemes. Table 4 is a supplement to Figs. 12 and 13; it provides summarized values for both plots and shows that the standard deviation of the two NF schemes is substantially lower than the standard deviation obtained for the conventional VBR system. Hence, there is much less burstiness in the two NF schemes. In Table 4, the GOP size is averaged for both systems, and the GOP sizes are slightly less under the two NF schemes as compared to the VBR scheme, which prevents data loss altogether while still maintaining image quality.

Fig. 14 provides the results for the conventional VBR system for the arrival rate R a and the actual bandwidth or actual transmission rate r actual . Fig. 15 depicts the available space in the token bucket for the conventional VBR system. Fig. 16 shows the proposed NF schemes with departure rate R d from the traffic-regulating buffer. As shown, the two NF schemes manipulate the MPEG encoder to regulate the bit rate in order to reduce burstiness much better than the conventional VBR system, which results in no data loss and a reduction in excessive delay, while maintaining image quality.

Fig. 17 shows the storage availabilities of the traffic-regulating buffer and the conventional token bucket. There is no data loss from implementing the two NF schemes. Comparing Figs. 10 and 17 demonstrates that for high variation in bit rate in a video clip such as ‘Superman Returns’, data loss could be improved, and with a low variation in bit rate in a video clip such as ‘The Santa Clause 3’, data loss could be prevented altogether. In Fig. 18 , there is no total data loss, and indeed, there is further capacity for additional transmission, which guarantees that a relatively low bit rate video clip such as ‘The Santa Clause 3’ could easily be transmitted without losing B- frames. Thus, there is no need for adding a default value upon reception. Table 5 is presented below to compare with Table 3. In Table 5, the data loss from the conventional token bucket of the VBR system is 10.6551%, whereas the proposed NF schemes do not exhibit any losses in either the token bucket or the traffic-regulating buffer. In comparison with Table 5, Table 3 demonstrates data loss at the traffic-regulating buffer using the two NF schemes.

The computer simulation results show a reduction in standard deviation and burstiness, a lower concentration of GOP size in one area and a broader distribution, and a higher average GOP size for transmission, all of which result in a decrease in data loss and time delay, and thus, an improvement in image quality. This is achieved with little computational overhead, which could reduce computational time, memory requirements and bandwidth optimization for real-time implementations in delay-sensitive video services in mobile devices. As can be seen in Section 3 entitled ‘Use of neuro-fuzzy techniques for arrival rate and departure rate’, the rules underlying the rule-based fuzzy system and the neural network controllers provide algorithmic efficiency and hence do not require excessive processing power.

Two neuro-fuzzy schemes are proposed to inspect the arrival rate and departure rate of a traffic-regulating buffer to assist a conventional token bucket in controlling the flow of MPEG video over 2.4-GHz Bluetooth. Comparing a conventional token bucket model with a conventional token bucket and a traffic-regulating buffer controlled by a two neuro-fuzzy model shows that the proposed novel design has more capacity for further data transmission, and it also reduces data loss. Furthermore, computer simulation graphs demonstrate that the new neuro-fuzzy schemes present higher density with respect to GOP size, a lower concentration of GOP size in one area, a broader distribution and less burstiness, all of which contribute to a decrease in excessive time delay and data loss, while maintaining image quality.

The rules underlying the rule-based fuzzy system at the input and the output of the traffic-regulating buffer are simple and effective and do not require excessive computational power. The neural networks update these rules according to changes encountered at the Bluetooth channel; they are also based on simple but very effective algorithms and thus do not require a disproportionate amount of power. Subsequently, the proposed neuro-fuzzy schemes are well suited to the real-time applications of delay-sensitive MPEG video over a 2.4-GHz frequency, as rules are constantly adjusted to provide the best effort throughput.

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: H.B. Kazemian (SM’1988) received a B.Sc. in Engineering from Oxford Brookes University, UK, a M.Sc. in Control Systems Engineering from the University of East London, UK, and a Ph.D. in Learning Fuzzy Controllers from Queen Mary University of London, UK, in 1985, 1987 and 1998, respectively. He is currently a full professor at London Metropolitan University, UK. He worked for Ravensbourne College University Sector, UK, as a senior lecturer for eight years. Previous lecturing experience includes the University of East London, UK, University of Northampton, UK, and Newham College, UK. Research interests include fuzzy and neuro-fuzzy control of networks, 2.4 GHz frequency bands, ATM, video streaming and rate control. Prof. Kazemian is a senior member of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (SMIEEE), Fellow of the Institution of Engineering and Technology FIET (formerly IEE) UK and Chartered Engineer (C. Eng.) UK.
